item.title: Forest Fitness
item.description:
Date: November 9, 2024

Join us for a free, year-round “Fitness at the Fort” exercise program on Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays!

This fitness class incorporates climbing multiple staircases, stretches and strengthening exercises, notable tree identification, and forest bathing. Led by instructor, Nancy Bruning, BA, MPH, PAPHS.

Classes are structured so that all levels of fitness will be accommodated; however, all classes involve relatively brisk walking and some stairs because of the layout of the park itself. Classes vary according to the season, path conditions, and the weather, but always meet at the Heather Garden entrance.

Tuesday and Thursday classes end at various points near the starting point, including the volleyball courts. Saturday class ends at the Anne Loftus Playground, using the various pieces of equipment, and offers optional after-class group walk to the Greenmarket on Isham Street. All classes end with closing with stretches.

(Note: Fitness Walking does not meet if it is raining or if the actual temperature or wind chill is below 20 degrees F.)

Start time: 8:30 am

End time: 9:30 am

Contact phone:

Location: Margaret Corbin Circle (in Fort Tryon Park)
item.event:location: Margaret Corbin Circle (in Fort Tryon Park)
item.event:categories: Outdoor Fitness | Exercise Classes | Walking

item.title: NYRR Open Run: Inwood Hill Park
item.description:
Date: November 9, 2024

NYRR Open Run Brings free, 5K weekly community-led runs, to neighborhood parks across the greater New York City area. The program is free and open to runners and walkers of all ages, abilities, and experience levels.

Evidence of Inwood Hill Park’s formation exists as caves, valleys, and ridges left as the result of shifting glaciers. Evidence of its uninhabited state afterward remains as its forest and salt marsh (the last natural one in Manhattan), and evidence of its use by Native Americans continues to be discovered. Most of the park was largely untouched by wars and development. The park features a hiking trail and the Hudson River Bike Trail, and is one of the best places in NYC to spot a bald eagle. It also includes athletic fields, playgrounds, dog runs, and a barbecue area.

The course is three loops on hilly trails and walkways through woods and along a salt marsh.

Start time: 8:45 am

End time: 10:30 am

Contact phone:

Location: Seaman Avenue and Isham Street Entrance (in Inwood Hill Park)
item.event:location: Seaman Avenue and Isham Street Entrance (in Inwood Hill Park)
item.event:categories: Sports | Running/Jogging | Walking

item.title: NYRR Open Run: Soundview Park
item.description:
Date: November 9, 2024

NYRR Open Run brings free, 5K weekly community-led runs, to neighborhood parks across the greater New York City area. The program is free and open to runners and walkers of all ages, abilities, and experience levels.

Called the “Gateway to the Bronx River,” 205-acre Soundview Park is located where the Bronx River opens into the East River. This urban green space is filled with grassy baseball and soccer fields, a cricket pitch, basketball courts, a running track, walking/biking paths, picnic fields, and more! With its extensive views of the water, Soundview Park celebrates the beauty of both the Bronx and East Rivers. The back part of our Open Run course has beautiful views of the Bronx River waterfront for participants to enjoy!

Start time: 9:00 am

End time: 12:00 pm

Contact phone:

Location: Entrance - Lafayette Avenue and Morrison Avenue (in Soundview Park)

item.title: NYRR Open Run: St. Marys Park
item.description:
Date: November 9, 2024

NYRR Open Run brings free, 5K weekly community-led runs, to neighborhood parks across the greater New York City area. The program is free and open to runners and walkers of all ages, abilities, and experience levels.

St. Mary's Park offers a wonderful respite from the hustle and bustle of urban life. Located in the Mott Haven neighborhood in the South Bronx, the park features rolling hills, expanses of green grass, and grand old trees. The site was once part of the estate of Jonas Bronck (1600-43), for whom the Bronx is named. It is one of the largest parks in the area with a pool, playground, basketball courts, an indoor recreation center, picnic seating areas, and more. In the winter, the hills are perfect for sledding. St. Mary’s Park received $30 million from NYC’s Anchor Parks initiative, which will renovate the park’s ballfields, pathways, and amphitheater.

Start time: 9:00 am

End time: 12:00 pm

Contact phone:

Location: 149th Street Entrance between St. Ann's Avenue and Eagle Avenue (in St. Mary's Park)
item.event:location: 149th Street Entrance between St. Ann's Avenue and Eagle Avenue (in St. Mary's Park)

item.title: Hattie Carthan Community Garden Saturday Market
item.description:
Date: November 9, 2024

Come to Hattie Carthan Community Market at 363-365 Clifton Place near Marcy Ave, Bed Stuy Brooklyn for the garden's weekly Saturday market until November 16th. While at the market, enjoy:

  • Free cooking demonstrations
  • Compost drop off
  • Cultural culinary offerings
  • Community Supported Medicine Program
  • Food Sovereignty Shares pickup
  • Fresh bread products
  • Holistic market
  • Children’s garden
  • And more!

For more information, visit the Hattie Carthan Community Garden Market website.

Start time: 9:00 am

End time: 3:00 pm

Contact phone:

Location: Hattie Carthan Community Farmers Market
item.event:categories: Markets | Food

item.title: Broadway Beautification Days at Fort Tryon Park
item.description:
Date: November 9, 2024

Join the Fort Tryon Park Trust and NYC Parks for some spring cleaning in Fort Tryon Park! Help beautify the park along the Broadway Promenade. Meet at the Broadway Greeting Garden at the Arden Street/Broadway entrance. Wear long pants, sturdy shoes, and get ready to improve the park’s ecology by removing debris and helping site preparations. Tools and gloves will be provided but please bring a filled water bottle.

Groups of 5+ must RSVP by emailing info@FortTryonParkTrust.org 2 weeks in advance.

Volunteers under age 18 must be accompanied by an adult.

Stewardship Days along the eastern expanse of the park take place on the 2nd & 4th Saturdays of each month from March to November. The Fort Tryon Park Trust supports these volunteer opportunities by underwriting tools, horticultural supplies, and NYC Parks staffing to oversee projects.

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 1:00 pm

Contact phone:

Location: Broadway/Arden Entrance (in Fort Tryon Park)
item.event:categories: Volunteer

item.description:

Volunteer with the Stewardship Team to plant trees in the forest of Idlewild Park! Come dressed in sturdy boots or shoes, long sleeves, long pants, and clothing that can get dirty. Volunteers under 18 must be accompanied by a chaperone. This event has been funded in part by NOAA. To sign up a group of 10 or more volunteers please reach out to stewardship@parks.nyc.gov.

item.title: Roots and Shoots Youth Brigade
item.description:
Date: November 9, 2024

Growing Leaders at Roots and Shoots Youth Brigade!

Is your child ready to become a leader while making a positive impact on the world?

Join the Roots and Shoots Youth Brigade at Eastern Queens Alliance! Our program empowers young minds to take charge, explore environmental initiatives, and develop leadership skills! Designed for ages 10-20, our program encourages children to take charge, be a voice for the planet, and become leaders in their community.

  • Help to plan and participate in service projects that tackle issues through action.
  • Meet and work with other youth activists who are changing the world! You don't have to wait until adulthood to lead us towards a better world.
  • Commit to taking Action.

Parents and children, please complete the mandatory RSVP form to join the brigade.

Start time: 11:00 am

End time: 1:00 pm

Contact phone:

Location: Entrance - Springfield Lane and 149th Avenue (in Idlewild Park)
item.event:location: Entrance - Springfield Lane and 149th Avenue (in Idlewild Park)
item.event:categories: Education | Nature | Volunteer | Workshops

item.title: Socrates x Noguchi Field Guide: Upcycling - The potential of paper
item.description:
Date: November 9, 2024

Socrates x Noguchi Field Guide:
Upcycling: Potential of Paper

Saturday, November 9 • 11AM–1PM • Pre-Registration Required • 15 Participants • All Ages Welcome • Free!

Facilitated by Joseph Tokumasu Field

Explore the many possibilities of mulberry paper while considering the intersections of ecology and economics in traditional Japanese handicrafts. Participants will create a traditional Japanese Uchiwa fan from upcycled materials and engage with Isamu Noguchi’s ideas about functionality and sustainable practices.

Pre-registration is recommended, with a limited number of walk-up spots available.

item.title: Greenbelt Geological Hike
item.description:
Date: November 9, 2024

Join us for the Greenbelt Geological Hike!

Event Location: Greenbelt Nature Center

The Greenbelt is located on the terminal moraine of the Wisconsin Glacier. During this hike through the central Greenbelt and past a serpentine ridge, see how glacial topography shaped the Greenbelt's past, charted a course for the present-day Greenbelt trails, and will help shape a sustainable, resilient future. Led by experienced guides, this in-person event will take you on a journey through the unique terrain of the area. Learn about the formation of the landscape, discover different rock formations, and uncover the secrets hidden beneath the surface. This hike is perfect for nature lovers, geology enthusiasts, and anyone looking for an adventure in the great outdoors. Don't miss out on this exciting opportunity to connect with nature and learn more about the world beneath your feet!

Sturdy footwear and dress for the weather

Will be canceled if we get extreme weather (call 718.351.3450 for information the day of the hike)

Registration required. Suitable for children 12+ yrs.

Start time: 11:00 am

End time: 1:00 pm

Contact phone: 718-351-3450

Location: Greenbelt Nature Center (in Blood Root Valley)

item.title: Conference House Tours
item.description:
Date: November 9, 2024

Tours are offered on Saturdays and Sundays from 12 - 4 pm until December 14th.

Don’t miss out on an opportunity to learn about this historic Staten Island landmark.

Site of the 1776 Peace Conference

Built by English immigrant Captain Christopher Billopp, in or around the year 1680, this handsome stately manor was a wheat farm throughout the first century of its existence. An invaluable relic in America’s history, the Conference House was the site of a 1776 peace conference which attempted to end the Revolutionary War. Edward Rutledge, John Adams, Lord Howe and Benjamin Franklin were among those in attendance. Surrounded by lush acreage of forests, marshland and meadows, the Conference House overlooks the Arthur Kill River, Lower Raritan Bay and nearby New Jersey. The history and location of our museum gives visitors a glimpse of a pre populated landscape of New York City, while also illustrating our nation’s history.

Come visit us!

Start time: 12:00 pm

End time: 4:00 pm

Contact phone: (718) 984-6046

Location: Conference House Museum (in Conference House Park)
item.event:location: Conference House Museum (in Conference House Park)
item.event:categories: History | Tours

item.title: Intro To Dance for Kids
item.description:
Date: November 9, 2024

Free VOLO KIDS Dance program in Partnership with NYC Parks. Dancers will be guided through 6-weeks of introductory dance classes. Every two weeks, dancers will visit a new dance style while building off the techniques and skills learned in previous weeks. The first two weeks will focus on Ballet. Dancers will learn the basics of ballet and implement them in other complex movements. The next two weeks will consist of Jazz and Contemporary styles using the ballet foundation. Dancers will learn the foundational techniques of these styles while learning to embed emotional expression into choreography. The final two weeks will focus on commercial dance styles such as Hip Hop, Musical Theater, and Commercial Jazz. These styles will encourage dancers to use their technique, emotion, and imagination to emulate the choreography they see in TV, movies, and professional performances. Dance games and short choreography combinations will help dancers memorize techniques and stylistic niches while developing a holistic understanding of the art of dance.

Start time: 12:00 pm

End time: 1:00 pm

Contact phone:

Location: Dance Room (in Marcus Garvey Park)

item.title: Killing an Evening with Edgar Allan Poe
item.description:
Date: November 9, 2024

Join John Kevin Jones (A Christmas Carol at the Merchant’s House) in the Merchant’s House Museum’s double parlor — set for a 19th century funeral complete with casket — for a hauntingly memorable performance of Poe’s “The Tell-Tale Heart,” “The Cask of Amontillado,” “The Angel of the Odd” and, of course, “The Raven.” It will be a bone-chilling evening of irrational revenge … obsession and premeditated murder … dismemberment … and the very, very dark.


Killing an Evening with Edgar Allan Poe is presented in association with Summoners Ensemble Theatre and directed by Dr. Rhonda Dodd.

item.title: LES Ecology Center Pumpkin Smash 2024
item.description:
Date: November 10, 2024

Don't let your pumpkin haunt a landfill! Join LES Ecology Center at La Plaza Cultural for Pumpkin Smash 2024 on Sunday, November 10th. Bring your pumpkins, jack-o-lanterns, and gourds for a smashing good time!

In addition, enjoy the following fun, family-friendly activities:

  • Earth Loom Weaving
  • Cooking Demos
  • Games & Giveaways
  • Live Music by Kicki & The Fellas
  • ...and more!

Smashed pumpkins will be turned into compost to help rejuvenate soils in parks and green spaces.

If your pumpkin is still edible, we encourage you to find a tasty recipe that utilizes the entire pumpkin!

Can’t make it? Bring your jack-o-lanterns to one of LES Ecology Center's food scrap drop-off sites.

FREE. Registration recommended; drop-ins welcome! This event is rain or shine and will proceed in light rain. In the case that there is inclement weather, we notify via this Eventbrite page and on our social media.

Start time: 12:00 pm

item.description:
Date: November 10, 2024

The Jeffrey's Hook lighthouse, erected in 1880 and moved to its current site in 1921, has become widely known as the children's literary landmark "The Little Red Lighthouse and the Great Gray Bridge." Rediscover the history of this unique landmark. Open access between 1:00pm and 2:45pm. Participants may need to queue for access due capacity limits inside of the structure. Enter park via overpass closest to Plaza Lafayette. (West 181st Street) and Riverside Drive.

Local historian and author Pat Salmon will present about how Staten Island was several centuries ago. Take us on a trip back in time through information gathered from research and archaeological digs related to the Lenape, the arrival of Early Europeans, African-American History, the Peace Conference, and more.

This program is sponsored by NYC City Council Discretionary Funds.

item.title: Killing an Evening with Edgar Allan Poe
item.description:
Date: November 10, 2024

Join John Kevin Jones (A Christmas Carol at the Merchant’s House) in the Merchant’s House Museum’s double parlor — set for a 19th century funeral complete with casket — for a hauntingly memorable performance of Poe’s “The Tell-Tale Heart,” “The Cask of Amontillado,” “The Angel of the Odd” and, of course, “The Raven.” It will be a bone-chilling evening of irrational revenge … obsession and premeditated murder … dismemberment … and the very, very dark.


Killing an Evening with Edgar Allan Poe is presented in association with Summoners Ensemble Theatre and directed by Dr. Rhonda Dodd.

  • Anitya: In Sanskrit means impermanence, passing or transient. Indeed, we all know that things constantly shift and change.
  • Interbeing: Everything relies on everything else in the cosmos in order to manifest—whether a star, a cloud, a flower, a bird, or you and me.
  • Bird Migration: Taking a journey that can stretch to a round-trip distance of several thousand miles is a dangerous and arduous undertaking.

item.title: Volunteer Workday: It's All About Brownsville
item.description:
Date: November 11, 2024

GreenThumb community gardens are developed, led, and cared for by dedicated volunteers who critically upkeep community gardens as public green spaces.

It's All About Brownsville is an active community garden in Brownsville, Brooklyn, engaging neighbors, young people, and local organizations in food cultivation, environmental sustainability, and community advocacy.

On this workday, volunteers will assist GreenThumb gardeners and staff in building and filling new raised beds for growing and distributing food to the community. Everyone is welcome to join, learn, and practice basic carpentry skills, including the use of power tools. Gloves and tools will be provided. Please bring water, snacks, and clothes and shoes/boots that you don’t mind getting dirty. Note that this activity is outdoors and may involve bending, kneeling, and lifting heavy materials.

Groups should contact the volunteer coordinator at Kyleen.Sanchez@parks.nyc.gov before signing up.

Location: 754 Thomas S Boyland St, Brooklyn 11212 (between Livonia Ave & Riverdale Ave)

This event is hosted by NYC Parks GreenThumb. We are proud to be the nation’s largest urban community gardening program, sustaining over 550 gardens throughout New York City. With GreenThumb’s support, community gardens are centers of environmental justice, ensuring that our city is fairer, safer, and greener for all. GreenThumb’s events are free and open to the public.

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 1:00 pm

Contact phone:

Location: It's All About Brownsville

item.title: Forest Fitness
item.description:
Date: November 12, 2024

Join us for a free, year-round “Fitness at the Fort” exercise program on Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays!

This fitness class incorporates climbing multiple staircases, stretches and strengthening exercises, notable tree identification, and forest bathing. Led by instructor, Nancy Bruning, BA, MPH, PAPHS.

Classes are structured so that all levels of fitness will be accommodated; however, all classes involve relatively brisk walking and some stairs because of the layout of the park itself. Classes vary according to the season, path conditions, and the weather, but always meet at the Heather Garden entrance.

Tuesday and Thursday classes end at various points near the starting point, including the volleyball courts. Saturday class ends at the Anne Loftus Playground, using the various pieces of equipment, and offers optional after-class group walk to the Greenmarket on Isham Street. All classes end with closing with stretches.

(Note: Fitness Walking does not meet if it is raining or if the actual temperature or wind chill is below 20 degrees F.)

item.title: Hart Island Tour (North Island)
item.description:
Date: November 12, 2024

Hart Island is the largest public cemetery in the country and has served New York City since 1869. Hart Island’s history is connected to many communities with important stories to tell. During the South Island Tour, Rangers will explore what Hart Island meant to the people who lived there, worked there, and were/are buried there. Walking the South Island includes discussion of an amusement park, military history, multiple pandemics, historic buildings and more. Join the Urban Park Rangers to hear their history and their voices.

Join the Urban Park Rangers to explore Hart Island's unique past, present, and future. Participants are chosen by lottery.

Lottery registration opens on Wednesday October 30 , 2024 and ends Thursday October 31, 2024 at 11:59 p.m.

Please Note:
-You must register each member of your party for the lottery under the same account. Anyone who was not registered will not be permitted to attend.

- If you are selected for the program, you will receive a series of emails confirming your selection and must respond as soon as possible to avoid forfeiting your spot.

- Hart Island is only accessible via ferry. Selected participants will be provided details regarding program arrival and other specifics.

- There are no indoor facilities, restrooms or drinking fountains on Hart Island. There are portable restrooms on the island.

- This tour covers historical context of Hart Island and is about two hours of walking, some parts on uneven terrain. Please dress appropriately for the weather and the terrain.

- Program may be cancelled due to inclement weather at the discretion of ferry operations.

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 12:30 pm

Contact phone:

Location: Hart Island
item.event:categories: Urban Park Rangers

item.title: Free Remote Sensing Workshop for Middle & High School Students
item.description:
Date: November 12, 2024

Event Description
Dive into the fascinating world of remote sensing at the Idlewild Environmental Learning Center! This 7-week workshop series introduces students to cutting-edge techniques that scientists use to study Earth's environment. Learn how light and its interaction with matter can help detect environmental changes in the atmosphere, geosphere, hydrosphere, and biosphere—and how you can contribute to protecting our planet.

Workshop Details:
- Middle School Sessions (Tuesdays): Hands-on research activities with an introduction to computer-based techniques. (Laptops provided)
Dates: November 5th, 12th, 19th, 26th; December 3rd, 10th, 17th
- High School Sessions (Fridays): Dive deeper into computer-based research techniques, including data analysis. (Laptops provided, but bringing your own is encouraged.

Dates: November 1st, 8th, 12th; December 6th, 13th, 20th

Whether you're passionate about science or looking for a new challenge, this is an amazing opportunity to explore the Earth from a whole new perspective. Plus, it's FREE!

**Limited spots available—register now!**

Start time: 3:30 pm

End time: 5:00 pm

Contact phone: 347-824-2301

Location: Entrance - Springfield Lane and 149th Avenue (in Idlewild Park)

item.title: Virtual Restorative Yoga
item.description:
Date: November 12, 2024

Connect with yourself in Slow Flow Yoga, a class to be enjoyed by all. For those who want to move but at a slower more therapeutic pace. Slow flow yoga connects movement with breath, emphasizing mindful engagement, awareness, and ease through each pose. As most postures are typically held longer than in more energetic forms of yoga, students have the time and space to move deliberately, explore subtler levels of alignment and deepen the stretch as they connect-in with their body. Recommended props for the class include: three large pillows (or as many as you need), two blankets, two blocks (or books to act as blocks), one eye pillow (or towel to cover eyes).

The Zoom link will be sent out three hours before the class and again right before the class starts to registered participants.

Start time: 6:00 pm

End time: 7:15 pm

Contact phone:

Location: Virtual/Online Events

item.title: Vault Hill Meadow Workday Wednesdays
item.description:
Date: November 13, 2024

Vault Hill Meadow Invasive Removal at Van Cortlandt Park

Join the Van Cortlandt Park Alliance in an ongoing effort to restore the natural biodiversity of Vault Hill Meadow by removing invasive plant species. This opportunity focuses on hands-on invasive species removal, with tasks varying seasonally to ensure the health and recovery of this important area within the park.

What to Expect:

• Seasonal invasive species removal: Volunteers will tackle invasive plants such as porcelain berry, multiflora rose, and others that pose a threat to native species.

• Hands-on fieldwork: Expect to get involved in physical tasks, including cutting, pulling, and gathering invasive plants.

• Equipment provided: Gloves, tools, and any other necessary equipment will be supplied.

What to Bring:

• Long sleeves, pants, and sturdy shoes

• Water and snacks

• Enthusiasm for fieldwork and environmental restoration

Location:

Meet at the southern end of the Van Cortlandt Golf House. From there, we’ll walk to Vault Hill Meadow to begin the day’s activities.

Sign-Up Details:

• Time: Select days, 9:00 AM - 12:00 PM

• RSVP: Spaces are limited to 30 volunteers per shift, so make sure to sign up early!

Why Participate?:

• Contribute to the restoration of Vault Hill Meadow, one of Van Cortlandt Park’s key areas for native biodiversity.

• Gain experience in invasive species management.

• Be part of an ongoing effort to improve the park’s ecological health.

Join us in restoring Vault Hill Meadow and make a lasting impact on Van Cortlandt Park’s natural beauty!

Start time: 9:00 am

End time: 12:00 pm

Contact phone:

Location: Van Cortlandt Golf House (in Van Cortlandt Park)
item.event:location: Van Cortlandt Golf House (in Van Cortlandt Park)
item.event:categories: Nature | Volunteer

item.title: Art Exhibition: Kenshō by Vince Serecin
item.description:
Date: November 13, 2024

Celebrate Birds with an exhibition: Kenshō, artwork by Vince Serecin.

  • Anitya: In Sanskrit means impermanence, passing or transient. Indeed, we all know that things constantly shift and change.
  • Interbeing: Everything relies on everything else in the cosmos in order to manifest—whether a star, a cloud, a flower, a bird, or you and me.
  • Bird Migration: Taking a journey that can stretch to a round-trip distance of several thousand miles is a dangerous and arduous undertaking.

Conference House Visitor Center & Lenape Gallery

298 Satterlee Street

Staten Island, NY 10307

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 3:00 pm

Contact phone: 917-886-4389

item.title: Forest Fitness
item.description:
Date: November 14, 2024

Join us for a free, year-round “Fitness at the Fort” exercise program on Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays!

This fitness class incorporates climbing multiple staircases, stretches and strengthening exercises, notable tree identification, and forest bathing. Led by instructor, Nancy Bruning, BA, MPH, PAPHS.

Classes are structured so that all levels of fitness will be accommodated; however, all classes involve relatively brisk walking and some stairs because of the layout of the park itself. Classes vary according to the season, path conditions, and the weather, but always meet at the Heather Garden entrance.

Tuesday and Thursday classes end at various points near the starting point, including the volleyball courts. Saturday class ends at the Anne Loftus Playground, using the various pieces of equipment, and offers optional after-class group walk to the Greenmarket on Isham Street. All classes end with closing with stretches.

(Note: Fitness Walking does not meet if it is raining or if the actual temperature or wind chill is below 20 degrees F.)

Start time: 7:30 am

End time: 8:30 am

Contact phone:

Location: Margaret Corbin Circle (in Fort Tryon Park)

Location: Van Cortlandt Park, Garden and Education Compost Site, across from Riverdale Stables.
Time: 9 am sharp; work begins at 9:15 am

Activities Include:
Repairing cross country trail surfaces
Clearing debris and overgrowth
Ensuring trail safety and accessibility

What to Bring:
Sunscreen
Comfortable, weather-appropriate clothing
Closed-toed shoes
Water and a snack

Why Join Us?
Contribute to the vitality and safety of the trails you love! Engage with fellow community members, learn about trail maintenance, and enjoy the satisfaction of hands-on work in the great outdoors.
Necessary tools and gloves will be provided!

item.title: Art Exhibition: Kenshō by Vince Serecin
item.description:
Date: November 14, 2024

Celebrate Birds with an exhibition: Kenshō, artwork by Vince Serecin.

  • Anitya: In Sanskrit means impermanence, passing or transient. Indeed, we all know that things constantly shift and change.
  • Interbeing: Everything relies on everything else in the cosmos in order to manifest—whether a star, a cloud, a flower, a bird, or you and me.
  • Bird Migration: Taking a journey that can stretch to a round-trip distance of several thousand miles is a dangerous and arduous undertaking.

Conference House Visitor Center & Lenape Gallery

298 Satterlee Street

Staten Island, NY 10307

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 3:00 pm

Contact phone: 917-886-4389

item.description:
Date: November 14, 2024

Explore Brooklyn Bridge Park like never before during Open Hours at the Environmental Education Center. New 2024 hours are Thursdays 3-5 PM, Fridays 3-5 PM, and Saturdays 1-5 PM! All sessions are free and drop-in; view dates and learn more at brooklynbridgepark.org.

Visitors of all ages can get to know Brooklyn Bridge Park with rotating monthly educational themes, a 250 gallon aquarium filled with critters from the East River, a 10’ scale model of Brooklyn Bridge Park, crafts, a reading corner, and much more. Open Hours offer the opportunity for self-led investigation with guidance by expert educators to reveal the hidden stories found within and around Brooklyn Bridge Park.

item.title: Community Ecology Reading Group: Trees, Wildlife, and Waterways Walk
item.description:
Date: November 14, 2024

The Community Ecology Reading Group has been meeting for exactly a year. In the past year we've explored trees, wildlife, and waterways and compiled a reading list on community ecology. In this meet-up, we'll culminate these themes with a group walk led by Dan Tainow. We'll meet at Collect Pond Park, follow Minetta Creek, and end at Washington Square Park where we'll meet the oldest trees of the park. The walk will cover approximately 1.5 miles.

This meet-up's theme is “people”. Please come with some media to share around this theme.

About the facilitator: Dan Tainow is an environmental educator and urban naturalist who has been working in NYC for the past 19 years. Dan has worked for the NYC Compost Project at Queens Botanical Garden, the Lower East Side Ecology Center, the School for Green Careers, and currently for NYC Parks.

This event is presented in partnership with Stuy Cove Park: Stuy Cove Park is a Lower Manhattan greenspace and educational hub for conversations on food, climate, and social justice. Built atop a former industrial site on stolen Lenape land, this city-owned property is managed by Solar One in partnership with the NYC Economic Development Corporation.

This event is hosted by NYC Parks GreenThumb. We are proud to be the nation’s largest urban community gardening program, sustaining over 550 gardens throughout New York City. With GreenThumb’s support, community gardens are centers of environmental justice, ensuring that our city is fairer, safer, and greener for all. GreenThumb’s events are free and open to the public.

Start time: 6:00 pm

End time: 7:30 pm

Contact phone:

Location: Collect Pond Park
item.event:categories: Education | Nature | Community Input Meetings | Wildlife | Workshops | Walking

NYRR Open Run Brings free, 5K weekly community-led runs, to neighborhood parks across the greater New York City area. The program is free and open to runners and walkers of all ages, abilities, and experience levels.

One of the city's most iconic parks, Flushing Meadows Corona Park was the site of two 20th-century World's Fairs. It features historic walks, scenic trails, sports venues, and facilities for activities including soccer, baseball, tennis, volleyball, cricket, and more, as well as a recreation center, an indoor pool, lakes, trails, and many cultural and civic institutions.

item.title: Forest Fridays at Van Cortlandt Park
item.description:
Date: November 15, 2024

Join Us for Forest Friday Events in the Fall!

What: Forest Restoration in the Northwest Forest

When: Fridays in November

Time: 9:00 AM - 12:00 PM (please arrive on time - we leave for the site by 9:15am)

Where: Van Cortlandt Park - Garden & Compost Site

Description:

Join us for our Forest Friday events! We will be focusing on removing invasive species like porcelain berry, bittersweet, multiflora rose, Norway Maple and more. These activities are crucial in preserving the health and biodiversity of our forest.

Activities Include:

  • Invasive Species Removal: Help us eradicate invasive plants that threaten our native ecosystem.
  • Forest Restoration: Assist in the restoration of native plants and habitats.
  • Hands-on Activities: Engage in practical conservation efforts that make a real difference.
  • Planting: Two sessions at the end of October will involve planting.

What to Bring:

  • Long sleeves and pants
  • Sturdy shoes
  • Water and snacks
  • Enthusiasm for environmental conservation!

Sign-Up Details:

  • Roles Available: General Volunteer
  • Signup Limit: 30 volunteers per shift

Waitlist: Available if slots are filled

Why Participate?

  • Contribute to the health of your local environment
  • Gain hands-on experience in conservation work
  • Meet like-minded individuals passionate about the environment

How to Sign Up:

  • Visit our InitLive Volunteer Page to view available shifts.
  • Sign up for the dates that work for you.
  • We look forward to seeing you there and making a positive impact together!

Start time: 9:00 am

End time: 12:00 pm

Contact phone:

Location: VCPA Garden & Compost Site (in Van Cortlandt Park)

item.title: Art Exhibition: Kenshō by Vince Serecin
item.description:
Date: November 15, 2024

Celebrate Birds with an exhibition: Kenshō, artwork by Vince Serecin.

  • Anitya: In Sanskrit means impermanence, passing or transient. Indeed, we all know that things constantly shift and change.
  • Interbeing: Everything relies on everything else in the cosmos in order to manifest—whether a star, a cloud, a flower, a bird, or you and me.
  • Bird Migration: Taking a journey that can stretch to a round-trip distance of several thousand miles is a dangerous and arduous undertaking.

Conference House Visitor Center & Lenape Gallery

298 Satterlee Street

Staten Island, NY 10307

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 3:00 pm

Contact phone: 917-886-4389

Visitors of all ages can get to know Brooklyn Bridge Park with rotating monthly educational themes, a 250 gallon aquarium filled with critters from the East River, a 10’ scale model of Brooklyn Bridge Park, crafts, a reading corner, and much more. item.title: Free Remote Sensing Workshop for Middle & High School Students
item.description:
Date: November 15, 2024

Please note: this event has been cancelled.

Event Description
Dive into the fascinating world of remote sensing at the Idlewild Environmental Learning Center! This 7-week workshop series introduces students to cutting-edge techniques that scientists use to study Earth's environment. Learn how light and its interaction with matter can help detect environmental changes in the atmosphere, geosphere, hydrosphere, and biosphere—and how you can contribute to protecting our planet.

Workshop Details:
- Middle School Sessions (Tuesdays): Hands-on research activities with an introduction to computer-based techniques. (Laptops provided)
Dates: November 5th, 12th, 19th, 26th; December 3rd, 10th, 17th
- High School Sessions (Fridays): Dive deeper into computer-based research techniques, including data analysis. (Laptops provided, but bringing your own is encouraged.

Dates: November 1st, 8th, 12th; December 6th, 13th, 20th

Whether you're passionate about science or looking for a new challenge, this is an amazing opportunity to explore the Earth from a whole new perspective. Plus, it's FREE!

**Limited spots available—register now!**

Start time: 3:30 pm

End time: 5:00 pm

Contact phone: 347-824-2301

Location: Entrance - Springfield Lane and 149th Avenue (in Idlewild Park)
item.event:location: Entrance - Springfield Lane and 149th Avenue (in Idlewild Park)
item.event:categories: Education | Best for Kids | Media Education | STEM Classes

item.title: Concert: Valery Ponomarev "We Have a Message" Quintet
item.description:
Date: November 15, 2024

Valery Ponomarev "We Have a Message" Quintet
Trumpeter Valery Ponomarev was born in Russia and came to the U.S. in 1973. Well-known for his four years with Art Blakey & the Jazz Messengers, with whom he performed at major concert halls, clubs, and festivals all over the world and recorded 11 albums, he has also worked with Benny Golson, Max Roach, Joe Henderson, Jimmy Cobb, Don Braden, Curtis Fuller, Charles McPherson, Arturo O'Farrill, the Duke Ellington Orchestra under Mercer and Paul Ellington, and many others. He has released eight solo albums, and two books, including On the Flip Side of Sound.

Presented by the Jazz Foundation of America, supported in part by an award from the National Endowment for the Arts, the New York State Council on the Arts with the support of the Office of the Governor and the New York State Legislature and by public funds from the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs in partnership with the City Council and by the Howard Gilman Foundation

Start time: 6:00 pm

End time: 7:30 pm

Contact phone:

Location: Asser Levy Recreation Center (in Asser Levy Playground)

item.title: Forest Fitness
item.description:
Date: November 16, 2024

Join us for a free, year-round “Fitness at the Fort” exercise program on Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays!

This fitness class incorporates climbing multiple staircases, stretches and strengthening exercises, notable tree identification, and forest bathing. Led by instructor, Nancy Bruning, BA, MPH, PAPHS.

Classes are structured so that all levels of fitness will be accommodated; however, all classes involve relatively brisk walking and some stairs because of the layout of the park itself. Classes vary according to the season, path conditions, and the weather, but always meet at the Heather Garden entrance.

Tuesday and Thursday classes end at various points near the starting point, including the volleyball courts. Saturday class ends at the Anne Loftus Playground, using the various pieces of equipment, and offers optional after-class group walk to the Greenmarket on Isham Street. All classes end with closing with stretches.

(Note: Fitness Walking does not meet if it is raining or if the actual temperature or wind chill is below 20 degrees F.)

Start time: 8:30 am

End time: 9:30 am

Contact phone:

Location: Margaret Corbin Circle (in Fort Tryon Park)

item.event:categories: Outdoor Fitness | Exercise Classes | Walking

item.title: NYRR Open Run: Inwood Hill Park
item.description:
Date: November 16, 2024

NYRR Open Run Brings free, 5K weekly community-led runs, to neighborhood parks across the greater New York City area. The program is free and open to runners and walkers of all ages, abilities, and experience levels.

Evidence of Inwood Hill Park’s formation exists as caves, valleys, and ridges left as the result of shifting glaciers. Evidence of its uninhabited state afterward remains as its forest and salt marsh (the last natural one in Manhattan), and evidence of its use by Native Americans continues to be discovered. Most of the park was largely untouched by wars and development. The park features a hiking trail and the Hudson River Bike Trail, and is one of the best places in NYC to spot a bald eagle. It also includes athletic fields, playgrounds, dog runs, and a barbecue area.

The course is three loops on hilly trails and walkways through woods and along a salt marsh.

Start time: 8:45 am

End time: 10:30 am

Contact phone:

Location: Seaman Avenue and Isham Street Entrance (in Inwood Hill Park)
item.event:location: Seaman Avenue and Isham Street Entrance (in Inwood Hill Park)
item.event:categories: Sports | Running/Jogging | Walking

item.title: NYRR Open Run: Soundview Park
item.description:
Date: November 16, 2024

NYRR Open Run brings free, 5K weekly community-led runs, to neighborhood parks across the greater New York City area. The program is free and open to runners and walkers of all ages, abilities, and experience levels.

Called the “Gateway to the Bronx River,” 205-acre Soundview Park is located where the Bronx River opens into the East River. This urban green space is filled with grassy baseball and soccer fields, a cricket pitch, basketball courts, a running track, walking/biking paths, picnic fields, and more! With its extensive views of the water, Soundview Park celebrates the beauty of both the Bronx and East Rivers. The back part of our Open Run course has beautiful views of the Bronx River waterfront for participants to enjoy!

item.title: NYRR Open Run: St. Marys Park
item.description:
Date: November 16, 2024

NYRR Open Run brings free, 5K weekly community-led runs, to neighborhood parks across the greater New York City area. The program is free and open to runners and walkers of all ages, abilities, and experience levels.

St. Mary's Park offers a wonderful respite from the hustle and bustle of urban life. Located in the Mott Haven neighborhood in the South Bronx, the park features rolling hills, expanses of green grass, and grand old trees. The site was once part of the estate of Jonas Bronck (1600-43), for whom the Bronx is named. It is one of the largest parks in the area with a pool, playground, basketball courts, an indoor recreation center, picnic seating areas, and more. In the winter, the hills are perfect for sledding. St. Mary’s Park received $30 million from NYC’s Anchor Parks initiative, which will renovate the park’s ballfields, pathways, and amphitheater.

Start time: 9:00 am

End time: 12:00 pm

Contact phone:

Location: 149th Street Entrance between St. Ann's Avenue and Eagle Avenue (in St. Mary's Park)

item.title: Volunteer Workday: Commitment Garden
item.description:
Date: November 16, 2024

GreenThumb community gardens are developed, led, and cared for by dedicated volunteers who critically upkeep community gardens as public green spaces.

Commitment Garden is a spacious, food-producing community garden in East New York, Brooklyn. Previously two separate spaces—Triple R Garden (Rest, Reflection, Relaxation) and New Vision Garden—the groups have now merged after removing the shared fence. They’re excited to welcome new members as they begin this new chapter together!

On this volunteer day, participants will help plant a garden border with native flowers and shrubs! Gloves and tools will be provided. Please bring water, snacks, and clothes and shoes/boots that you don’t mind getting dirty. Note that this activity is outdoors and will involve bending, kneeling, and lifting heavy materials.

Groups should contact the volunteer coordinator at Kyleen.Sanchez@parks.nyc.gov before signing up.

Location: 590 Schenck Avenue, Brooklyn 11207 (between Dumont Ave & Livonia Ave)

This event is co-hosted by NYC Parks GreenThumb. We are proud to be the nation’s largest urban community gardening program, sustaining over 550 gardens throughout New York City. With GreenThumb’s support, community gardens are centers of environmental justice, ensuring that our city is fairer, safer, and greener for all. GreenThumb’s events are free and open to the public.

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 2:00 pm

Contact phone:

Location: Commitment Garden
item.event:categories: Nature | Volunteer | Wildlife | Gardening

item.title: Conference House Tours
item.description:
Date: November 16, 2024

Tours are offered on Saturdays and Sundays from 12 - 4 pm until December 14th.

Don’t miss out on an opportunity to learn about this historic Staten Island landmark.

Site of the 1776 Peace Conference

Built by English immigrant Captain Christopher Billopp, in or around the year 1680, this handsome stately manor was a wheat farm throughout the first century of its existence. An invaluable relic in America’s history, the Conference House was the site of a 1776 peace conference which attempted to end the Revolutionary War. Edward Rutledge, John Adams, Lord Howe and Benjamin Franklin were among those in attendance. Surrounded by lush acreage of forests, marshland and meadows, the Conference House overlooks the Arthur Kill River, Lower Raritan Bay and nearby New Jersey. The history and location of our museum gives visitors a glimpse of a pre populated landscape of New York City, while also illustrating our nation’s history.

Come visit us!

Start time: 12:00 pm

End time: 4:00 pm

Contact phone: (718) 984-6046

Location: Conference House Museum (in Conference House Park)

item.title: Intro To Dance for Kids
item.description:
Date: November 16, 2024

Free VOLO KIDS Dance program in Partnership with NYC Parks. Dancers will be guided through 6-weeks of introductory dance classes. Every two weeks, dancers will visit a new dance style while building off the techniques and skills learned in previous weeks. The first two weeks will focus on Ballet. Dancers will learn the basics of ballet and implement them in other complex movements. The next two weeks will consist of Jazz and Contemporary styles using the ballet foundation. Dancers will learn the foundational techniques of these styles while learning to embed emotional expression into choreography. The final two weeks will focus on commercial dance styles such as Hip Hop, Musical Theater, and Commercial Jazz. These styles will encourage dancers to use their technique, emotion, and imagination to emulate the choreography they see in TV, movies, and professional performances. Dance games and short choreography combinations will help dancers memorize techniques and stylistic niches while developing a holistic understanding of the art of dance.

Start time: 12:00 pm

End time: 1:00 pm

Contact phone:

Location: Dance Room (in Marcus Garvey Park)

Visitors of all ages can get to know Brooklyn Bridge Park with rotating monthly educational themes, a 250 gallon aquarium filled with critters from the East River, a 10’ scale model of Brooklyn Bridge Park, crafts, a reading corner, and much more. item.title: Nighthunters: Meet the Owls
item.description:
Date: November 16, 2024

Join us at Wave Hill for an exclusive adventure to engage with owls of all shapes and sizes. Birders and nature lovers will be treated to a special after-hours experience as the sun sets over the Hudson and nocturnal creatures come to life. Falconers Brian and Teddy Bradley and their spectacular live owls headline the evening with an exciting indoor program introducing these amazing birds of prey. Feel the wind brush your face as they fly silently inches above your head and get an intimate look at their adaptations and hunting techniques. Bring your cameras for incredible close-ups! Afterwards, venture outside for an optional nighttime nature walk with local NYC naturalists Gabriel Willow, and Ryan Mandelbaum to listen and look for nocturnal creatures in the shadowy nighttime gardens. You won’t believe you’re in the Bronx! 21 and older.

Start time: 5:30 pm

End time: 9:00 pm

Contact phone: 718.549.3200

item.description:

Tools and gloves will be provided, but wear long pants, sturdy shoes, a face mask as needed, and bring a filled water bottle,

Groups of 5+ RSVP by emailing info@FortTryonParkTrust.org a week in advance so we can provide sufficient equipment and tools on hand.

Volunteers under 18 must be accompanied by an adult.

Stewardship Days along the southwest area of Fort Tryon Park take place on the 3rd Sunday of each month from March to November.

item.title: Conference House Tours
item.description:
Date: November 17, 2024

Tours are offered on Saturdays and Sundays from 12 - 4 pm until December 14th.

Don’t miss out on an opportunity to learn about this historic Staten Island landmark.

Site of the 1776 Peace Conference

Built by English immigrant Captain Christopher Billopp, in or around the year 1680, this handsome stately manor was a wheat farm throughout the first century of its existence. An invaluable relic in America’s history, the Conference House was the site of a 1776 peace conference which attempted to end the Revolutionary War. Edward Rutledge, John Adams, Lord Howe and Benjamin Franklin were among those in attendance. Surrounded by lush acreage of forests, marshland and meadows, the Conference House overlooks the Arthur Kill River, Lower Raritan Bay and nearby New Jersey. The history and location of our museum gives visitors a glimpse of a pre populated landscape of New York City, while also illustrating our nation’s history.

Come visit us!

Start time: 12:00 pm

End time: 4:00 pm

Contact phone: (718) 984-6046

Location: Conference House Museum (in Conference House Park)

item.title: Art Exhibition: Kenshō by Vince Serecin
item.description:
Date: November 18, 2024

Celebrate Birds with an exhibition: Kenshō, artwork by Vince Serecin.

  • Anitya: In Sanskrit means impermanence, passing or transient. Indeed, we all know that things constantly shift and change.
  • Interbeing: Everything relies on everything else in the cosmos in order to manifest—whether a star, a cloud, a flower, a bird, or you and me.
  • Bird Migration: Taking a journey that can stretch to a round-trip distance of several thousand miles is a dangerous and arduous undertaking.

Conference House Visitor Center & Lenape Gallery

298 Satterlee Street

Staten Island, NY 10307

item.title: Forest Fitness
item.description:
Date: November 19, 2024

Join us for a free, year-round “Fitness at the Fort” exercise program on Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays!

This fitness class incorporates climbing multiple staircases, stretches and strengthening exercises, notable tree identification, and forest bathing. Led by instructor, Nancy Bruning, BA, MPH, PAPHS.

Classes are structured so that all levels of fitness will be accommodated; however, all classes involve relatively brisk walking and some stairs because of the layout of the park itself. Classes vary according to the season, path conditions, and the weather, but always meet at the Heather Garden entrance.

Tuesday and Thursday classes end at various points near the starting point, including the volleyball courts. Saturday class ends at the Anne Loftus Playground, using the various pieces of equipment, and offers optional after-class group walk to the Greenmarket on Isham Street. All classes end with closing with stretches.

(Note: Fitness Walking does not meet if it is raining or if the actual temperature or wind chill is below 20 degrees F.)

Start time: 7:30 am

End time: 8:30 am

Contact phone:

Location: Margaret Corbin Circle (in Fort Tryon Park)

item.title: Art Exhibition: Kenshō by Vince Serecin
item.description:
Date: November 19, 2024

Celebrate Birds with an exhibition: Kenshō, artwork by Vince Serecin.

  • Anitya: In Sanskrit means impermanence, passing or transient. Indeed, we all know that things constantly shift and change.
  • Interbeing: Everything relies on everything else in the cosmos in order to manifest—whether a star, a cloud, a flower, a bird, or you and me.
  • Bird Migration: Taking a journey that can stretch to a round-trip distance of several thousand miles is a dangerous and arduous undertaking.

Conference House Visitor Center & Lenape Gallery

298 Satterlee Street

Staten Island, NY 10307

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 3:00 pm

Contact phone: 917-886-4389

Location: Visitor Center - Satterlee Street and Hylan Boulevard (in Conference House Park)

item.title: Free Remote Sensing Workshop for Middle & High School Students
item.description:
Date: November 19, 2024

Event Description
Dive into the fascinating world of remote sensing at the Idlewild Environmental Learning Center! This 7-week workshop series introduces students to cutting-edge techniques that scientists use to study Earth's environment. Learn how light and its interaction with matter can help detect environmental changes in the atmosphere, geosphere, hydrosphere, and biosphere—and how you can contribute to protecting our planet.

Workshop Details:
- Middle School Sessions (Tuesdays): Hands-on research activities with an introduction to computer-based techniques. (Laptops provided)
Dates: November 5th, 12th, 19th, 26th; December 3rd, 10th, 17th
- High School Sessions (Fridays): Dive deeper into computer-based research techniques, including data analysis. (Laptops provided, but bringing your own is encouraged.

Dates: November 1st, 8th, 12th; December 6th, 13th, 20th

Whether you're passionate about science or looking for a new challenge, this is an amazing opportunity to explore the Earth from a whole new perspective. Plus, it's FREE!

**Limited spots available—register now!**

Start time: 3:30 pm

End time: 5:00 pm

Contact phone: 347-824-2301

Location: Entrance - Springfield Lane and 149th Avenue (in Idlewild Park)

item.title: Organizing for Garden Success: Bylaws (Part 2 of 2)
item.description:
Date: November 19, 2024

This two–part workshop series is designed to help your garden group build a strong foundation to deal with the many issues that arise in a community space. In this workshop, we will discuss writing garden bylaws that outline processes for decision–making and garden governance, and that will satisfy the GreenThumb requirement for bylaws.

This is an interactive webinar. Register to receive the zoom link. We will not be recording.

This event is hosted by NYC Parks GreenThumb. We are proud to be the nation’s largest urban community gardening program, sustaining over 550 gardens throughout New York City. With GreenThumb’s support, community gardens are centers of environmental justice, ensuring that our city is fairer, safer, and greener for all. GreenThumb’s events are free and open to the public.

item.description:

NYRR Open Run brings free, weekly community-led, approximately 3 mile runs to neighborhood parks across the greater New York City area. The program is free and open to runners and walkers of all ages, abilities, and experience levels.

The Open Run route offers views of the Brooklyn Bridge on the way out, the Statue of Liberty on the way back, and the Lower Manhattan skyline the whole way. Fornino is a great spot to get drinks and pizza after the run.

item.title: Vault Hill Meadow Workday Wednesdays
item.description:
Date: November 20, 2024

Vault Hill Meadow Invasive Removal at Van Cortlandt Park

Join the Van Cortlandt Park Alliance in an ongoing effort to restore the natural biodiversity of Vault Hill Meadow by removing invasive plant species. This opportunity focuses on hands-on invasive species removal, with tasks varying seasonally to ensure the health and recovery of this important area within the park.

What to Expect:

• Seasonal invasive species removal: Volunteers will tackle invasive plants such as porcelain berry, multiflora rose, and others that pose a threat to native species.

• Hands-on fieldwork: Expect to get involved in physical tasks, including cutting, pulling, and gathering invasive plants.

• Equipment provided: Gloves, tools, and any other necessary equipment will be supplied.

What to Bring:

• Long sleeves, pants, and sturdy shoes

• Water and snacks

• Enthusiasm for fieldwork and environmental restoration

Location:

Meet at the southern end of the Van Cortlandt Golf House. From there, we’ll walk to Vault Hill Meadow to begin the day’s activities.

Sign-Up Details:

• Time: Select days, 9:00 AM - 12:00 PM

• RSVP: Spaces are limited to 30 volunteers per shift, so make sure to sign up early!

Why Participate?:

• Contribute to the restoration of Vault Hill Meadow, one of Van Cortlandt Park’s key areas for native biodiversity.

• Gain experience in invasive species management.

• Be part of an ongoing effort to improve the park’s ecological health.

Join us in restoring Vault Hill Meadow and make a lasting impact on Van Cortlandt Park’s natural beauty!

Start time: 9:00 am

End time: 12:00 pm

Contact phone:

Location: Van Cortlandt Golf House (in Van Cortlandt Park)

item.title: Art Exhibition: Kenshō by Vince Serecin
item.description:
Date: November 20, 2024

Celebrate Birds with an exhibition: Kenshō, artwork by Vince Serecin.

  • Anitya: In Sanskrit means impermanence, passing or transient. Indeed, we all know that things constantly shift and change.
  • Interbeing: Everything relies on everything else in the cosmos in order to manifest—whether a star, a cloud, a flower, a bird, or you and me.
  • Bird Migration: Taking a journey that can stretch to a round-trip distance of several thousand miles is a dangerous and arduous undertaking.

item.title: Forest Fitness
item.description:
Date: November 21, 2024

Join us for a free, year-round “Fitness at the Fort” exercise program on Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays!

This fitness class incorporates climbing multiple staircases, stretches and strengthening exercises, notable tree identification, and forest bathing. Led by instructor, Nancy Bruning, BA, MPH, PAPHS.

Classes are structured so that all levels of fitness will be accommodated; however, all classes involve relatively brisk walking and some stairs because of the layout of the park itself. Classes vary according to the season, path conditions, and the weather, but always meet at the Heather Garden entrance.

Tuesday and Thursday classes end at various points near the starting point, including the volleyball courts. Saturday class ends at the Anne Loftus Playground, using the various pieces of equipment, and offers optional after-class group walk to the Greenmarket on Isham Street. All classes end with closing with stretches.

(Note: Fitness Walking does not meet if it is raining or if the actual temperature or wind chill is below 20 degrees F.)

Start time: 7:30 am

End time: 8:30 am

Contact phone:

Location: Margaret Corbin Circle (in Fort Tryon Park)

item.description:
Date: November 21, 2024

Explore Brooklyn Bridge Park like never before during Open Hours at the Environmental Education Center. New 2024 hours are Thursdays 3-5 PM, Fridays 3-5 PM, and Saturdays 1-5 PM! All sessions are free and drop-in; view dates and learn more at brooklynbridgepark.org.

Visitors of all ages can get to know Brooklyn Bridge Park with rotating monthly educational themes, a 250 gallon aquarium filled with critters from the East River, a 10’ scale model of Brooklyn Bridge Park, crafts, a reading corner, and much more. Open Hours offer the opportunity for self-led investigation with guidance by expert educators to reveal the hidden stories found within and around Brooklyn Bridge Park.

item.title: Music in the Lobby
item.description:
Date: November 21, 2024

Join NYC Parks and experience the beauty of classical music reimagined through the captivating voices of the cello quartet. From the heroic melodies of Wiłkomirski to the ethereal dreamscapes of Debussy, and the icy passion of Vivaldi's Winter, this concert takes audiences on a mesmerizing journey through
the depths of human emotion and imagination.

Thursday, November 21, 2024 | 5:00 p.m. – 6:30 p.m.

Jackie Robinson Recreation Center | (212) 234-9606
85 Bradhurst Ave., New York, N.Y. 10039

To RSVP, email Richard.Martinez@parks.nyc.gov

This event is FREE and open to the public. Please bring a lock to secure your belongings. For
more information, visit nyc.gov/parks or email Saudia.Thompson@parks.nyc.gov. Contact
accessibility@parks.nyc.gov or (212) 360-1430 for more information regarding accessibility.

Start time: 5:00 pm

item.description:
Date: November 21, 2024

NYRR Open Run Brings free, 5K weekly community-led runs, to neighborhood parks across the greater New York City area. The program is free and open to runners and walkers of all ages, abilities, and experience levels.

One of the city's most iconic parks, Flushing Meadows Corona Park was the site of two 20th-century World's Fairs. It features historic walks, scenic trails, sports venues, and facilities for activities including soccer, baseball, tennis, volleyball, cricket, and more, as well as a recreation center, an indoor pool, lakes, trails, and many cultural and civic institutions.

item.description:
Date: November 22, 2024

Join the Bronx River Alliance in a series of stewardship days to protect and sustain the Long Island Sound habitat at Concrete Plant Park. Help establish a native plant habitat to feed and house migratory birds and pollinators.

Drop ins are welcome, but register here to stay in the loop with updates and cancellations! We take a break from 12pm-1pm. We get back to the stewardship event after 1pm.
For questions or concerns, email Foodway@bronxriver.org or call 718-542.4121.

This event is generously supported by by the Long Island Sound Study and Restore America’s Esturaries.

Start time: 9:00 am

End time: 3:00 pm

Contact phone: 718-542.4121

Location: Concrete Plant Park

item.title: Forest Fridays at Van Cortlandt Park
item.description:
Date: November 22, 2024

Join Us for Forest Friday Events in the Fall!

What: Forest Restoration in the Northwest Forest

When: Fridays in November

Time: 9:00 AM - 12:00 PM (please arrive on time - we leave for the site by 9:15am)

Where: Van Cortlandt Park - Garden & Compost Site

Description:

Join us for our Forest Friday events! We will be focusing on removing invasive species like porcelain berry, bittersweet, multiflora rose, Norway Maple and more. These activities are crucial in preserving the health and biodiversity of our forest.

Activities Include:

  • Invasive Species Removal: Help us eradicate invasive plants that threaten our native ecosystem.
  • Forest Restoration: Assist in the restoration of native plants and habitats.
  • Hands-on Activities: Engage in practical conservation efforts that make a real difference.
  • Planting: Two sessions at the end of October will involve planting.

What to Bring:

  • Long sleeves and pants
  • Sturdy shoes
  • Water and snacks
  • Enthusiasm for environmental conservation!

Sign-Up Details:

  • Roles Available: General Volunteer
  • Signup Limit: 30 volunteers per shift

Waitlist: Available if slots are filled

Why Participate?

  • Contribute to the health of your local environment
  • Gain hands-on experience in conservation work
  • Meet like-minded individuals passionate about the environment

How to Sign Up:

  • Visit our InitLive Volunteer Page to view available shifts.
  • Sign up for the dates that work for you.
  • We look forward to seeing you there and making a positive impact together!

Start time: 9:00 am

End time: 12:00 pm

Contact phone:

Location: VCPA Garden & Compost Site (in Van Cortlandt Park)

item.title: Art Exhibition: Kenshō by Vince Serecin
item.description:
Date: November 22, 2024

Celebrate Birds with an exhibition: Kenshō, artwork by Vince Serecin.

  • Anitya: In Sanskrit means impermanence, passing or transient. Indeed, we all know that things constantly shift and change.
  • Interbeing: Everything relies on everything else in the cosmos in order to manifest—whether a star, a cloud, a flower, a bird, or you and me.
  • Bird Migration: Taking a journey that can stretch to a round-trip distance of several thousand miles is a dangerous and arduous undertaking.

Conference House Visitor Center & Lenape Gallery

298 Satterlee Street

Staten Island, NY 10307

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 3:00 pm

Contact phone: 917-886-4389

Location: Visitor Center - Satterlee Street and Hylan Boulevard (in Conference House Park)

item.title: Free Remote Sensing Workshop for Middle & High School Students
item.description:
Date: November 22, 2024

Event Description
Dive into the fascinating world of remote sensing at the Idlewild Environmental Learning Center! This 7-week workshop series introduces students to cutting-edge techniques that scientists use to study Earth's environment. Learn how light and its interaction with matter can help detect environmental changes in the atmosphere, geosphere, hydrosphere, and biosphere—and how you can contribute to protecting our planet.

Workshop Details:
- Middle School Sessions (Tuesdays): Hands-on research activities with an introduction to computer-based techniques. (Laptops provided)
Dates: November 5th, 12th, 19th, 26th; December 3rd, 10th, 17th
- High School Sessions (Fridays): Dive deeper into computer-based research techniques, including data analysis. (Laptops provided, but bringing your own is encouraged.

Dates: November 1st, 8th, 12th; December 6th, 13th, 20th

Whether you're passionate about science or looking for a new challenge, this is an amazing opportunity to explore the Earth from a whole new perspective. Plus, it's FREE!

**Limited spots available—register now!**

item.title: Forest Fitness
item.description:
Date: November 23, 2024

Join us for a free, year-round “Fitness at the Fort” exercise program on Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays!

This fitness class incorporates climbing multiple staircases, stretches and strengthening exercises, notable tree identification, and forest bathing. Led by instructor, Nancy Bruning, BA, MPH, PAPHS.

Classes are structured so that all levels of fitness will be accommodated; however, all classes involve relatively brisk walking and some stairs because of the layout of the park itself. Classes vary according to the season, path conditions, and the weather, but always meet at the Heather Garden entrance.

Tuesday and Thursday classes end at various points near the starting point, including the volleyball courts. Saturday class ends at the Anne Loftus Playground, using the various pieces of equipment, and offers optional after-class group walk to the Greenmarket on Isham Street. All classes end with closing with stretches.

(Note: Fitness Walking does not meet if it is raining or if the actual temperature or wind chill is below 20 degrees F.)

Start time: 8:30 am

End time: 9:30 am

Contact phone:

Location: Margaret Corbin Circle (in Fort Tryon Park)

item.title: NYRR Open Run: Inwood Hill Park
item.description:
Date: November 23, 2024

NYRR Open Run Brings free, 5K weekly community-led runs, to neighborhood parks across the greater New York City area. The program is free and open to runners and walkers of all ages, abilities, and experience levels.

Evidence of Inwood Hill Park’s formation exists as caves, valleys, and ridges left as the result of shifting glaciers. Evidence of its uninhabited state afterward remains as its forest and salt marsh (the last natural one in Manhattan), and evidence of its use by Native Americans continues to be discovered. Most of the park was largely untouched by wars and development. The park features a hiking trail and the Hudson River Bike Trail, and is one of the best places in NYC to spot a bald eagle. It also includes athletic fields, playgrounds, dog runs, and a barbecue area.

The course is three loops on hilly trails and walkways through woods and along a salt marsh.

Start time: 8:45 am

End time: 10:30 am

Contact phone:

Location: Seaman Avenue and Isham Street Entrance (in Inwood Hill Park)

item.event:categories: Sports | Running/Jogging | Walking

item.title: NYRR Open Run: Soundview Park
item.description:
Date: November 23, 2024

NYRR Open Run brings free, 5K weekly community-led runs, to neighborhood parks across the greater New York City area. The program is free and open to runners and walkers of all ages, abilities, and experience levels.

Called the “Gateway to the Bronx River,” 205-acre Soundview Park is located where the Bronx River opens into the East River. This urban green space is filled with grassy baseball and soccer fields, a cricket pitch, basketball courts, a running track, walking/biking paths, picnic fields, and more! With its extensive views of the water, Soundview Park celebrates the beauty of both the Bronx and East Rivers. The back part of our Open Run course has beautiful views of the Bronx River waterfront for participants to enjoy!

item.title: NYRR Open Run: St. Marys Park
item.description:
Date: November 23, 2024

NYRR Open Run brings free, 5K weekly community-led runs, to neighborhood parks across the greater New York City area. The program is free and open to runners and walkers of all ages, abilities, and experience levels.

St. Mary's Park offers a wonderful respite from the hustle and bustle of urban life. Located in the Mott Haven neighborhood in the South Bronx, the park features rolling hills, expanses of green grass, and grand old trees. The site was once part of the estate of Jonas Bronck (1600-43), for whom the Bronx is named. It is one of the largest parks in the area with a pool, playground, basketball courts, an indoor recreation center, picnic seating areas, and more. In the winter, the hills are perfect for sledding. St. Mary’s Park received $30 million from NYC’s Anchor Parks initiative, which will renovate the park’s ballfields, pathways, and amphitheater.

Start time: 9:00 am

End time: 12:00 pm

item.title: Broadway Beautification Days at Fort Tryon Park
item.description:
Date: November 23, 2024

Join the Fort Tryon Park Trust and NYC Parks for some spring cleaning in Fort Tryon Park! Help beautify the park along the Broadway Promenade. Meet at the Broadway Greeting Garden at the Arden Street/Broadway entrance. Wear long pants, sturdy shoes, and get ready to improve the park’s ecology by removing debris and helping site preparations. Tools and gloves will be provided but please bring a filled water bottle.

Groups of 5+ must RSVP by emailing info@FortTryonParkTrust.org 2 weeks in advance.

Volunteers under age 18 must be accompanied by an adult.

Stewardship Days along the eastern expanse of the park take place on the 2nd & 4th Saturdays of each month from March to November. The Fort Tryon Park Trust supports these volunteer opportunities by underwriting tools, horticultural supplies, and NYC Parks staffing to oversee projects.

Our Historic New York programs highlight the history and architecture of selected neighborhoods or parks.Join Urban Park Rangers from the Bronx & Manhattan on a 2.5 mile journey of New York City’s metropolitan marvel: the Old Croton Aqueduct. This is a continuation of a series about the Old Croton Aqueduct Trail. This collaboration will begin at the Northern end of Aqueduct Walk and end at the High Bridge Water Tower. item.title: Conference House Tours
item.description:
Date: November 23, 2024

Tours are offered on Saturdays and Sundays from 12 - 4 pm until December 14th.

Don’t miss out on an opportunity to learn about this historic Staten Island landmark.

Site of the 1776 Peace Conference

Built by English immigrant Captain Christopher Billopp, in or around the year 1680, this handsome stately manor was a wheat farm throughout the first century of its existence. An invaluable relic in America’s history, the Conference House was the site of a 1776 peace conference which attempted to end the Revolutionary War. Edward Rutledge, John Adams, Lord Howe and Benjamin Franklin were among those in attendance. Surrounded by lush acreage of forests, marshland and meadows, the Conference House overlooks the Arthur Kill River, Lower Raritan Bay and nearby New Jersey. The history and location of our museum gives visitors a glimpse of a pre populated landscape of New York City, while also illustrating our nation’s history.

Come visit us!

Start time: 12:00 pm

End time: 4:00 pm

Contact phone: (718) 984-6046

Location: Conference House Museum (in Conference House Park)

item.description:
Date: November 23, 2024

Visitors of all ages can get to know Brooklyn Bridge Park with rotating monthly educational themes, a 250 gallon aquarium filled with critters from the East River, a 10’ scale model of Brooklyn Bridge Park, crafts, a reading corner, and much more. Open Hours offer the opportunity for self-led investigation with guidance by expert educators to reveal the hidden stories found within and around Brooklyn Bridge Park.
